title: 103_s2407
content:
The "Judicial Amendments Act of 1994" may be cited as the short title. Amendments to the Judiciary Automation Fund are included in the Act. Section 612 of title 28, United States Code, is amended to include program activities for courts and judicial services, support personnel, and costs for managing automatic data processing equipment purchased by the Fund. Agencies of the judiciary can also make deposits into the Fund for their data processing needs. Section 612 of title 28, United States Code is amended to include program activities for courts and judicial services, support personnel, and costs for managing automatic data processing equipment purchased by the Fund. This includes provisions for collecting fees under specific sections of the Judiciary Appropriations Act. In subsection (e)(1), the bill removes references to specific dollar amounts and replaces them with estimated collections under subsection (c) for the fiscal year. Subsection (h) is amended to require the Director to submit an annual report to Congress on the Fund's operation, including inventory, use, and acquisition of automatic data processing equipment, along with amounts deposited into the Fund. The Director must report on progress in improving the automation plan and strategic business plan, compare planned Fund expenditures with actual expenditures, and explain any delays or budget overruns. Additionally, the Judicial Conference may transfer up to $1,000,000 from the Fund. The Judicial Conference may transfer up to $1,000,000 from the Fund into the original account. Excess transfers require compliance with reprogramming procedures. The Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Court must develop a strategic business plan. The Judicial Conference may transfer funds from the Fund into the original account. The Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Court must develop a strategic business plan that includes missions, goals, objectives, automation plan, oversight of court automation efforts, life cycle management standards, case management and financial systems, and data communications network assessment. In this section, the year 1994 is changed to 1997 and the term "Judicial Services Account" is replaced with "fund established under section 1931 of this title". The text chunk "SEC. 3. COURT ARBITRATION AUTHORIZATION." is a condensed version of the previous information provided. SEC. 4. EXTENSION OF CIVIL JUSTICE EXPENSE AND DELAY REDUCTION PILOT PROGRAMS. Amendments are made to the Civil Justice Reform Act of 1990 to extend certain pilot programs. Amendments are made to the Civil Justice Reform Act of 1990 to extend certain pilot programs, including extending the time periods from 4 years to 5 years in subsection (a)(1), from 3 years to 4 years in subsection (b)(3), and changing the deadline from December 31, 1995, to December 31, 1996, in subsection (c)(1). "Speaker of the House of Representatives and Vice President of the United States, also President of the Senate."
